snippet: California's tough "three strikes and you're out" statute is having a dramatic effect on the state's criminal justice system, but not precisely what its supporters intended when Gov. Pete Wilson signed it into law a year ago.   Most defendants in ...
lead_paragraph: California's tough "three strikes and you're out" statute is having a dramatic effect on the state's criminal justice system, but not precisely what its supporters intended when Gov. Pete Wilson signed it into law a year ago. Most defendants in felony cases are now refusing to accept plea bargains, since three convictions mandate a sentence of 25 years to life. As a result, courts in many areas are clogged, county jails are overcrowded and nonviolent inmates are being released early.

headline.main: '3 Strikes' Law in California Is Clogging Courts and Jails
